Thoko's FantaPine
 Sed 
 
 Khothatso Ranosi and
 Marion Drew 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was a warm day in Malealea. 
 
 Thoko was siting on his father’s wagon.
 It was piled high with mielies. 
 There were many children on the wagon.
 
 They were going home after spending
 the whole day in the fields. 
 
 They had al worked hard that day.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Thoko was very lucky. 
 He worked the hardest of al the children. 
 So his father had bought him a 
 
 FantaPine drink from M’e Pontso’s shop. 
 “Mm, m it is delicious,” said 
 Thoko. 
 
 It was Thoko’s favourite drink. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He siped it slowly. He wanted it to last
 him until they got to the top of the hil.
 
 At the top of the hil his father stoped to
 give the oxen a rest. 
 “What a beautiful valey we live in
 
 children,” he said. 
 “We are lucky to live in such a clean,
 
 fresh place.” He smiled. 
 On they went. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 The sun was warm. 
 
 The wagon was rocking gently from side 
 to side as the oxen walked. 
 
 The children were chating softly to each 
 other. 
 Thoko felt slepy. 
 
 He wanted to lie down on the mielies and 
 slep a litle. 
 He loked at the empty FantaPine tin in 
 
 his hand. 
 “I am tired of holding this empty tin,” he 
 
 thought to himself. 
 What can I do with it?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Thoko thought for a minute. 
 
 Then he threw that FantaPine tin as far
 as he could out into the field. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Whe! That tin flew over the 
 field. 
 
 Twok! It landed in one of the furows. 
 The children laughed. 
 “Aie, Thoko is god at throwing!” they 
 
 said. 
 “Lok how far he threw that FantaPine 
 
 tin!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Thoko’s father turned around. 
 
 He stoped the wagon. 
 “What did you throw into my field
 
 Thoko?” he asked. 
 “I threw my FantaPine tin father,” said
 Thoko. 
 
 “Why did you do that Thoko?” asked his
 father. 
 
 “I was tired of holding it, and it made my
 fingers sticky,” said Thoko. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Let me ask you something, Thoko,” said 
 his father. 
 
 “Do I grow FantaPine in my fields?” 
 “Hahahahahahaha,” the children laughed. 
 “Aie, no, no, no, of course not father,” 
 
 Thoko said. 
 “Have you sen FantaPine growing on 
 the stalks in the sumer Thoko?” 
 
 “ Hehahahahahaha,” laughed the 
 children. 
 
 “No father, never,” said Thoko. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Have you sen us harvesting FantaPine
 in winter in my fields Thoko?” asked his
 
 father. 
 “Who, he, ha, ha, ha!” laughed
 the children. 
 
 “No father, we do not,” said Thoko.
 “Do you se us taking FantaPine tins
 home on my wagon to eat?” his father
 
 went on. 
 “Absolutely not, my father,” said Thoko.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Does your mother grind FantaPine tins 
 
 to make sorghum poridge Thoko?” 
 The children were laughing so much they 
 had to hold onto the sides of the wagon. 
 
 But Thoko could se that his father was 
 not hapy. 
 
 “Never father.” said Thoko. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “So Thoko, answer me please,” said his
 father. “What do I grow in my fields?”
 
 “You grow corn and sorghum in your
 fields father,” answered Thoko. 
 “Yes,” said Thoko’s father, “you are right.
 
 So I am asking myself a question. Why is
 my son planting FantaPine tins in my
 
 field, when he knows very wel that I grow
 only corn and sorghum?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The children stoped laughing. 
 There was silence on the wagon. 
 
 Thoko loked at his father. 
 His father was frowning. 
 He said, “Thoko, you get down of this 
 
 wagon right now. 
 You go and find that FantaPine tin and 
 
 you bring it back here at once!” 
 He spoke in a big, loud voice. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 Thoko felt ashamed. 
 
 He got down of the wagon and went into
 the field. 
 
 He loked for his empty FantaPine tin.
 There it was, shining in the sun.
 He walked over to it. 
 
 Just as he was about to pick it up, he
 noticed a dirty plastic bag lying nearby.
 Thoko stoped and thought about that
 
 plastic bag. 
 Then he walked over to it and picked it
 
 up. 
 He went back to the wagon. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 His father was waiting for him. 
 “What have you got there, Thoko?” he 
 
 asked. 
 “I have my FantaPine tin and a plastic 
 
 bag father, he said. 
 "I se,” said his father. 
 "Yes,” said Thoko. 
 
 ”I said to myself, my father grows only 
 corn and sorghum in his fields. 
 
 He does not grow FantaPine drinks, and 
 he also does not grow plastic bags in his 
 fields.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Thoko, I am very proud of you my son,”
 said his father. 
 “Children, let’s al go into the field. We wil
 
 se if there are other plastic bags, and
 tins and other things that we don’t grow
 there,” he said. 
 
 “Mm, god idea!” said Thoko. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The children claped their hands and 
 
 jumped down of the wagon. 
 They ran into the field. 
 They found many plastic bags, papers, 
 
 tins and boxes there. 
 “These must not be planted in the fields,” 
 they said. 
 
 When they came back to the wagon, their 
 arms were ful of al the rubish. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Put them al here children," said Thoko’s
 
 father. 
 "We wil take them home and burn them.
 We do not want these things in our fields.
 
 These things we canot grow. These
 things are not god for our soil."
 "Yes, yes!" said the children.
 
 
 Everybody got back onto the wagon.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 17  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Thoko’s father whistled to the oxen. 
 The wagon began to move again. 
 “Thoko,’ said his father, ‘tel me, do you 
 
 think our fields are hapy now?’ 
 ‘Yes, father,’ said Thoko, smiling. ‘And me 
 to, I am hapy now.’ 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 18
